Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the catalysts. (*) associated with CeO2 diffraction peak (#) derived from Al2O3 diffraction peak. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HAADF of Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 (a), Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 (b) and Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 (c) and the corresponding elemental mapping images. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts. Inner: the deconvolution of the peaks of Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectrum of the calcinated catalysts (a) and the catalysts after reduction (b). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 SEM-EDS analysis of the catalysts: SEM images (up) and corresponding element analysis (bottom). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Ce 3d XPS of reduced catalysts: (a) Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3, (b) Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and (c) Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Hydrogenation of 4-hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone over Pt catalysts. 0.2 g catalyst; 0.15 g 4-hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone; 15 mL isopropanol, 4 MPa H2, 70 °C for 2.5 h. TOF was calculated in the initial stage of the reaction (0∼10 min) with the reactant conversion lower than 15 %. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) Selectivity as a function of H2 consumption, (b) linear fitting of the selectivity and the H2 consumption (R2 = 0.997). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Catalytic results over different catalysts under different reaction condition (H2 pressure). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 (a) XRD patterns of the catalysts, and (b) H2-TPR profiles. (*) associated with CeO2 diffraction peak ( # ) derived from Al2O3 diffraction peak. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Dehydration of 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol to isoprene using heteropolyacid catalysts in the presence of cyclohexane/water solvent. Graphical abstract An alternative route to produce isoprene was reported, involving efficiently converting the adduct of formaldehyde and methyl ethyl ketone to a nonlinear C5 1,3-diol over ceria doped Pt-based catalysts. Isoprene has outmost importance in the manufacture of elastomer. Herein, an alternative approach for isoprene production from readily available chemicals is reported: condensation of methyl ethyl ketone and formaldehyde, followed by the hydrogenation and dehydration reaction. The focus was paid on the hydrogenation reaction over Pt-ceria catalysts giving 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol, where the influence of Ce species on the catalyst structure was studied, and the structure-activity relationship was established. It deduced that the presence of CeO2 appeared to be essential for the catalyst structure (e.g., dispersion, morphology) and the enhanced catalytic performance (e.g., activating H2, facilitating the reaction), these benefited from the presence of the oxygen vacancies on CeO2 surface. In addition, a relatively weak Pt-support interaction gave larger Pt particles which resulted in a higher yield. Finally, the application of the as-synthesized 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol in isoprene production was performed in the presence of the heteropolyacid catalysts, affording isoprene in ∼80 % yield. Keywords Isoprene production Methyl ethyl ketone C5 diols Pt based catalysts 1 Introduction The context of bioeconomy greatly prompts the design of sustainable processes for fuel and chemical production because of continuously diminishing availability of petrochemicals. Methyl ethyl ketone (MEK) is a readily available chemical, its production from bio-derived resources (e.g., 2,3-butanediol, levulinic acid) always is highly efficient [1]. MEK has been widely used in painting and coatings [2]. Recently, MEK was identified to be a promising candidate for the biofuel and chemical production. For example, MEK has the same engine efficiency as ethanol, whereas, MEK offers a higher combustion heat, better cold-start property, less oil dilution and lower hydrocarbon emissions [3]. Our group is interested in exploring its application in producing isoprene which has a significant importance in manufacture elastomer. Currently, isoprene is produced by extraction from the C5 fraction of naphtha cracking, or by catalytic transformation of fossil-derived chemicals (e.g., propylene, isobutene and isopentane) [4,5]. Abdelrahman et al. first reported a route to synthesize isoprene via the catalytic conversion of bio-derived chemicals, in which itaconic acid as substrate was converted to 3-methyl-tetrahydrofuran in the presence of Pd-Re/C catalyst under severe reaction conditions (typically, 200 °C, 7 MPa H2), followed by dehydra-decyclization to isoprene. Whereas, this method afforded a 70 % selectivity at only 20∼25 % conversion [6]. Therefore, the availability of feedstock and efficient approach for isoprene production are still lacking. Herein, we developed an alternative approach for isoprene production from MEK and formaldehyde under mild conditions, where a C5 diol with a desirable structure for isoprene production was synthesized. C5 diols can be produced through many catalytic routes by using various feedstocks, such as furfural, levulinic acid and γ-valerolactone [7,8]. And these processes afford the products mainly consisting of 1,5-, 1,4- and 1,2-diols. Whereas, the transformation of these products (e.g., 1,5- and 1,4-diols) to isoprene is always accompanied by the formation of a large amount of cyclic ethers, which was associated with the positions of the hydroxyl groups. Wang et al. synthesized a C5 diol with the hydroxyl groups at 1,3-position (3-methyl-1,3-butanediol) by using isobutene and formaldehyde as feedstock [9]. 3-Methyl-1,3-butanediol has been confirmed to serve as an important intermediate for the condensation of isobutene with formaldehyde to isoprene [10–12]. Consequently, 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol can be efficiently converted to isoprene. With this regard, a nonlinear C5 1,3-diol would be an ideal candidate for isoprene production. Unfortunately, isobutene is obtained as a byproduct in the steam cracking of naphtha, and the availability and the price of isobutene almost rely on the capacity of the ethylene industry, these afford significant limitations for isobutene application. In this context, the condensation of MEK with formaldehyde affords a promising precursor of a nonlinear C5 1,3-diol, which gives a probability for isoprene production from readily available and renewable chemicals. The hydrogenation reaction can be efficiently performed over Pt-based catalysts under mild conditions [13,14]. And one of the primary concerns for the Pt-based catalysts is the metal dispersion and the catalyst stability, because the Pt agglomeration always leads to the deterioration of the catalytic activity. In addition, the electronic properties of the active site can be tuned by creating defects on supports or adding other metals (e.g., Ce, Co) with controlling the metal nanoparticle size, these would be beneficial for the improvement of the selectivity because of the enhanced electron transfer and synergetic effects between Pt and metals [15,16]. Accordingly, supporting Pt on reducible metal oxides, such as CeO2, afforded a high dispersion and enhanced thermal stability because of the strong interaction between Pt and reducible metal oxides [17,18]. Moreover, the defects (oxygen vacancies) on CeO2 associating with Ce3+/Ce4+ provide frustrated Lewis pairs which play prominent role in H2 dissociation [19,20]. And the defects serving as Lewis-acid sites facilitate the adsorption of CO group. Besides, the presence of CeO2 gives a higher electron density at Pt, which leads to the polarization of the CO group [21,22]. In present work, ceria was used to modify Pt-based catalysts to synthesize a nonlinear C5 1,3-diol (2-methyl-1,3-butanediol) through hydrogenation reaction, and MEK and formaldehyde were employed as feedstocks. The Pt-ceria catalysts with Pt species on/in CeO2 (Pt-Cex/Al2O3, Pt/Ce/Al2O3) were prepared. And the optimized catalyst allowed the hydrogenation reaction undergoing at 70 °C with an excellent yield (95 % at 98 % conversion). The effects of Ce species on the catalyst structure were studied, and the structure-activity relationship was established. It suggests the presence of CeO2 plays a key role in the catalyst structure (e.g., dispersion, morphology), activating H2 and facilitating the reaction, because of the presence of the oxygen vacancies. And the application of 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol in isoprene production was also given. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Commercially available reagents, H2PtCl6·6H2O (Shanghai Jiuling), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Energy chemical), Al2O3, (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), methyl ethyl ketone (MEK, Energy chemical), formalin (37 %, Xilong Scientific), dodecane (TCI, Shanghai) and isobutanol (Beijing chemicals) were used as received. And H3PW12O40·xH2O (HPW), H3PMo12O40·xH2O (HPMo) and H4SiW12O40·xH2O (HSiW) were from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Pt-ceria catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness method. Typically, 127 mg of H2PtCl6·6H2O was dissolved in 3 mL water, after addition of 0.3 g Ce(NO)3·6H2O to form a homogeneous liquid, 3.0 g of Al2O3 was then added under stirring. Prior to aging overnight at room temperature, the mixture was treated by ultrasound for 1 h, followed by removal of the water at 80 °C, then dried at 120 °C for 5 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 4 h in sequence. The obtained sample was referred to as Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3, with 4.50 denoting CeO2 content determining by ICP. Similarly, Pt-Cex/Al2O3 catalysts (with x = 9.18, 11.40 and 16.60) were prepared by respectively adding 0.6, 0.9 and 1.2 g of Ce(NO)3·6H2O in 3 mL water, where 133, 140, 145 mg of H2PtCl6·6H2O were respectively employed to keep about 1.46 wt% Pt loadings. Pt/Ce/Al2O3 was prepared by similar operations with some modifications: 3.0 g of Al2O3 was added into 3 mL of Ce(NO)3·6H2O aqueous solution (Ce(NO)3·6H2O, 0.9 g) under stirring. Prior to aging overnight at room temperature, the mixture was treated by ultrasound for 1 h, followed by removal of the water at 80 °C, then dried at 120 °C for 5 h and calcined at 500 °C in air for 4 h in sequence. The obtained sample was added into 3 mL H2PtCl6·6H2O aqueous solution (H2PtCl6·6H2O, 140 mg) under stirring, then aged, dried and calcined by similar procedures. The as-prepared catalyst was referred as Pt/Ce/Al2O3. Similarly, Ce/Pt/Al2O3 was prepared by impregnating Pt and Ce in sequence. Pt/CeO2 was prepared as comparison, 127 mg of H2PtCl6·6H2O was dissolved in 27 mL water, 3.0 g of CeO2 was added. The as-prepared sample was referred as Pt/CeO2. The CeO2 support was prepared by calcination of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O at 550 °C for 4 h. All the catalysts were treated at 400 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2.5 °C /min in of H2/Ar (10 % H2, 80 mL/min) atmosphere prior to use. 2.3 Characterization Nitrogen adsorptiondesorption analysis was performed on Autosorb-iQ (Quantachrome). X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE (Cu Kα radiation, λ =0.154 nm). Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis was conducted on ThermoScientific Xseries II. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on ESCALAB 250, Thermo. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (Oxford Instruments X-MAX) was conducted on a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800, Xl-30 ESEM FEG). Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM), high-resolution TEM, high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and element mapping analysis were conducted on Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was carried out on SDT Q600 from room temperature to 800 °C under air atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The sample was heated from 50 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of H2/Ar flow (10 %, 50 mL/min). Prior to the experiment, the sample was pretreated at 500 °C in air for 1 h, and at 150 °C in a He flow (50 mL/min) for 30 min. 2.4 Synthesis of C5 diol from MEK and formaldehyde MEK and formaldehyde were used to synthesize 4-hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone at room temperature in the presence of KOH according to the reported work with modification (Supporting Information) [23,24]. And the transformation of 4-hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone to C5 diol was conducted in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with an inner Teflon coating. For typical procedures, 200 mg catalyst, 15 mL isopropanol and 0.15 g 4-hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone were added into the autoclave in sequence. The reactor was then purged with 2 MPa H2 for three times prior to being sealed. The hydrogenation reaction was carried out at 4 MPa H2 and at 50 ∼ 70 °C for 145 min. Upon completion, the reactor was cooled at 0 °C. The products were analyzed by GC–MS (Agilent 5975 MSD with Agilent SE-54), the quantitative analysis was conducted on GC (Agilent Technologies 7890B) using dodecane as internal standard. Turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated based on the platinum concentration determined using ICP, under the conditions: in the initial stage of the reaction (0–30 min), and with the reactant conversion lower than 15 %. (S1) T O F ( s - 1 ) = R a t e s o f h y d r o g e n a t i o n r e a c t i o n ( μ m o l · g c a t - 1 · s - 1 ) N u m b e r o f s u r f a c e P t a t o m s ( μ m o l · g c a t - 1 ) 4-Hydroxy-3-methyl-2-butanone: 1H NMR (600 MHz), δ = 3.71(ddd, 1 H), 3.63 (ddd, 1 H), 2.75 (ddq, 1 H), 2.35 (dd, 1H, OH), 2.18 (s, 3H, COCH3), 1.06 (d, 3 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz), δ = 212, 63, 48, 28, 12. 2-Methyl-1,3-butanediol, 13C NMR (100 MHz): δ = 68, 63, 39, 18, 10. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of the catalysts The main characteristics were summarized in Table 1 , and the results of N2 adsorption-desorption of Pt-ceria catalysts and their corresponding Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore distributions were presented in Fig. S1. N2 adsorption isotherms exhibited type IV adsorption isotherm curves indicating the presence of the mesopores in the catalysts. And the BJH pore distributions suggested the mesopores with size of 4∼12 nm in diameter. In addition, a slight decrease in both the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts was observed: Al2O3 (specific surface area: 246 m2/g, pore volume: 0.57 cc/g) > Pt/Al2O3 (243 m2/g, 0.56 cc/g) > Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3 (224 m2/g, 0.48 cc/g) > Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 (218 m2/g, 0.46 cc/g) > Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 (207 m2/g, 0.45 cc/g) > Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 (187 m2/g, 0.40 cc/g). Considering the ICP results, we presume the textural properties of the catalysts cannot be significantly changed by adding Pt because of its slight content (<2 wt%). Consequently, the changes mentioned above mainly resulted from the increase in CeO2 content. In present work, we tried to identify the effects of CeO2 on catalytic properties, thus the catalysts with various CeO2 loadings were employed. Although the slight differences in Pt loading (from 1.25 to 1.62 wt%) were observed, the catalysts had a well order in Pt/Ce atom ratio: Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3 (0.40) > Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 (0.21) > Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 (0.15) > Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 (0.12). The XRD patterns of the catalysts were presented in Fig. 1 . All the catalysts had a significant peak at approx. 67.0° which was related to the alumina support. And the diffraction peaks located at approx. 28.4°, 33.0°, 47.5° and 56.1° can be ascribed to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) reflections of the fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS PDF #65-2975), respectively. Obviously, no feature peak of CeO2 (e.g., located at 28.4°, 33.0° and 56.1°) was observed for Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3. And the increase in Ce loadings resulted in more pronounced diffraction peaks of CeO2. These can be owed to that some reﬂections of CeO2 phase overlapped with those of the alumina phase. It suggested that XRD diffraction peaks of CeO2 bulk will be observed at CeO2 content of greater than 6 wt% CeO2/Al2O3 [25,26]. Consequently, Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 exhibited an apparent crystalline CeO2 structure because of the appearance of the peaks at 28.4°, 33.0°, 47.5° and 56.1°. On the other hand, the intensity of Al2O3 diffraction peaks (e.g., at 37°, 46° and 67.0°) significantly decreased with the increasing of CeO2 content, and the Al2O3 phase was almost undetectable in Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3. These may imply the segregation of CeO2 on Al2O3 surface or the formation of CeO2 conglomerates covering Al2O3 phase, consequently, affording the decrease in surface area and pore volume of the catalysts. In addition, the weak diffraction peaks of CeO2 also suggested the smaller crystallite size. Therefore, the observation of weak diffraction peaks of CeO2 (e.g., Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3, Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3) may suggest that the small CeO2 particles with well dispersion would be obtained on the catalysts these had relatively low CeO2 loadings. No characteristic diffraction peaks of Pt species were observed, which can be attributed to the slight Pt content or the much small particle sizes. Generally, the crystallite <4 nm was undetectable by XRD. In present work, the Pt particles with a diameter of 0.8–2.8 nm were observed in Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 (Fig. S2). Thus, it is reasonable to believe that the Pt particles well dispersed on the support with small sizes. Fig. 2 shows the catalyst morphologies from TEM. The particles with 2–8 nm were CeO2. The crystalline and defective particles were clearly found in the high resolution TEM images (Fig. 2c and d), where an interplanar spacing of approx. 0.32 (d 111) nm was observed. And the observation of CeO2 (111) facet was in agreement with the XRD results. It was not easy to tell Pt particles from CeO2 particles in the presence of Al2O3 because of the trace of Pt in present work. Therefore, the elemental distribution of the catalysts was checked by high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM), and the elemental mapping with a randomly selected area was displayed in Fig. 3 . Clearly, Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and both Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 had a uniform Ce and Pt distribution compared with Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3. Interesting, the Pt loading of Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 (1.56 wt%) was comparable to that of Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 (1.62 wt%), whereas Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 presented poor distributions of both Pt and CeO2. This may suggest the CeO2 played a crucial role in Pt dispersion. Intuitively, Fig. 3(c) and corresponding mapping images illustrated that a good Pt dispersion was obtained at relatively low CeO2 loading, and the appearance of non-uniform Pt always was accompanied by the agglomeration of CeO2 particles. Accordingly, the formation of CeO2 conglomerates will occur at high CeO2 loadings (Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3), which gives a poor distribution of Pt. This was evidenced by XRD results. Therefore, the Ce distribution played a crucial role in Pt morphology. Notably, Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 still had relative small particles with good dispersion (Fig. S2), compared with Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3. This was in consistent with XRD results. H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts were presented in Fig. 4 . Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3, Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 with relatively low CeO2 contents (4.50, 9.18 and 11.40 wt%, respectively) had one reduction peak appearing at approx. 230 °C. In contrast, Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 with a relatively high loading of CeO2 (16.60 wt%) had two reduction peaks with considerable overlap at 206 °C and 240 °C. Moreover, a broad reduction peak at temperature range of 600∼800 °C appeared with the increase of CeO2 loadings, and the H2-TPR profiles of Pt/CeO2 and Pt/Al2O3 were displayed as comparison (Fig. S3). It is well known that the removal of the surface oxygen of CeO2 can be conducted at lower temperature because the surface oxygen is under-coordinated (2–3 instead of 4), whereas, the removal of the bulk oxygen of CeO2 requires a high temperature [27,28]. Accordingly, the reduction peak at temperature range of 600–800 °C was assigned to the reduction of bulk CeO2. And the peak at lower temperature (<300 °C) generally derived from the reduction of Pt species interacting strongly with CeO2 (PtOCe) or support, while the reduction of the surface ceria cannot be ruled out [17,26,28,29]. Thus, the reduction of PtOCe and the surface ceria gave rise to the formation of metallic Pt and surface oxygen vacancies, respectively. Notably, the reduction temperature of the peak (at 230 °C) in present work was significant higher than that in the reported studies (typically <200 °C, e.g., 190 °C) [30]. In those studies, the Pt particles were loaded on CeO2 surface by using incipient wetness impregnation method with Pt solution. Lee et al. suggested the diffusion of Pt species from ceria surface into the bulk would result in the increase in reduction temperature, typically from 165 °C to ∼240 °C [27]. Considering the procedures of the catalyst preparation in present work, where a solution containing Pt and Ce was employed to impregnate the support, it was reasonable to believe the partial Pt particles was trapped into the CeO2. H2 consumption was calculated from the area of reduction peak at <300 °C and summarized in Table 1. The addition of Ce greatly improved the H2 consumption of the catalysts compared to Pt/Al2O3 (68 μmol/g), which implied that both Pt-O–Ce and surface oxygen of CeO2 can react with H2 below 300 °C, resulting in the formation of metallic Pt and surface oxygen vacancies. An increase in H2 consumption was observed for Pt-Cex/Al2O3 (x = 4.50, 9.18, 11.40 and 16.60) with the increasing CeO2 loadings. And the correlation between H2 consumption and CeO2 loadings also suggested that H2 consumption can be mainly assigned to the reduction of Ce species (Fig. S4). In this view, the difference in H2-TPR peaks between Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 and the other catalysts may imply the appearance of the different states of CeO2. Generally, the reduction temperature of transition metal oxides is mostly influenced by their particle sizes [31]. For Pt/Al2O3, it has clarified that the increase in Pt loadings could lead to larger particles and higher reduction degree, which afforded a lower reduction temperature. Contrarily, a well dispersed Pt with small particles on Al2O3 could be obtained because of the strong interaction between Pt and support, consequently, giving a higher reduction temperature [32]. Thus, it inferred that Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 consisted of two states of CeO2 which may owe to the agglomeration or sintering of CeO2, affording different Pt species. In contrast, it could exhibit a uniform CeO2 state in Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3, Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. These were in accord with the results of XRD and HAADF. Based on these, the catalysts were divided into: a) group 1 (G1) with low CeO2 loadings and relatively good dispersion (Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3, Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3), b) group 2 (G2) with relative high CeO2 loading (Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3). Fig. 5 (a) illustrates the Raman spectrum of calcined catalysts. An increase in CeO2 loadings gave an increase in the intensity of Raman peaks, in particular for the peaks at approx. 455 and 668 cm−1. No distinct peak associated with alumina was observed. The peak at approx. 455 cm−1 (labeled as A) derived from the F2g symmetrical stretching vibration mode of CeO2 in a fluorite structure. And the peaks at approx. 550 (labeled as B) and 668 cm−1 (labeled as C) were assigned to the bridging PtOCe vibration and PtO vibration of PtOCe bond, respectively [27,33]. Therefore, Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3 having no significant Raman peak was owed to its low CeO2 content (4.50 wt%). Contrarily, Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 with the highest CeO2 loading (16.60 wt%) presented a high peak A. Interestingly, a relatively higher peak C compared with peak A was observed in H2-TPR curves of Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. And Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 had a TPR peak C which was comparable to the peak A. These results suggested that Pt species located on the surface of Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 was more than that on the surface of Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3. XRD results suggested the agglomeration of CeO2 particles in Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3, which resulted in the enrichment of Pt species (inferred from HAADF results). Thus it may deduce the large amount of Pt particles was encapsulated in CeO2 layers in Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3, giving a decrease in Pt particles on catalyst surface. This also demonstrated the significant differences between G2 and G1 catalysts. SEM-EDS was performed to identify the element distribution on catalyst surface (Fig. 6 ). The Pt/Ce atom ratio from EDS was lower than that from ICP, this demonstrated that the partial Pt species was encapsulated in CeO2 layers. Notably, Raman spectrum with 532 nm laser identifies the information on the several atomic layers of catalyst surface. [34] Thus, the trapped Pt particles in near-surface ceria layers in all the catalyst cannot be ruled out. Considering the catalyst preparation in present work, it inferred that the Pt particles disperse on ceria surface and/or were trapped in near-surface ceria layers when CeO2 loadings were low (e.g., Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3). It is well known that the Raman peak at approx. 600 cm−1 would be observed for ceria-based catalysts because of the presence of oxygen vacancies in CeO2. Slavinskaya et al. [35] suggested this peak shifting to 550 cm−1 after calcination of samples. Thus the peak at 550 cm−1 also identified the defect modes of ceria-based catalysts. Therefore, the peak at approx. 550 cm−1 suggested the presence of defect sites, which could be created by: a) the oxygen vacancy related to the redox cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+; b) the under-coordinated electronic environment caused by distributing Pt into CeO2 lattice (e.g., formation of PtOCe bond). [36,37] Nevertheless, the distributing Pt into CeO2 lattice led to the formation of a Pt-Ce solid solution, which did not evidenced by XRD because the presence of Al2O3 support in present work. On the other hand, the Raman spectrum of the catalysts after reduction was displayed in Fig. 5(b). The comparison illustrated that a significant decrease in the intensity of Raman peak at approx. 668 cm−1, and a slight decrease in the intensity of Raman peak at approx. 550 cm−1 were observed after reduction (Fig. S6). Accordingly, the decrease in the peak C resulted from the reduction of PtO of PtOCe, which would give rise to the reduction of bridging PtOCe, consequently, leading to a proportionate decrease in peak B. Whereas, this was not obverted in present work. In this view, the peak B mainly originated from the presence of the oxygen vacancies. The presence of the oxygen vacancies always was associated with the Ce3+, XPS was performed to further clarify this. Considering the differences between G1 and G2 catalysts, here, the G1 catalysts were determined. Fig. 7 displays the Ce 3d XPS spectra of the catalysts after reduction. The Ce 3d spectra can be fitted into ten peaks and always referred as v0 (881.6), v (883.2), v' (886.4), v” (889.0), v”' (898.6 eV), u0 (899.6), u (902.1), u' (905.3), u” (908.9) and u”' (917.8), where v and u related to the spin-orbit coupling 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively [38,39]. For instance, some deconvoluted peaks were shown in the spectra of Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. Generally, v, v”, v”', u, u” and u”' were attributed to the existence of Ce4+, and v0, v', u0 and u' indicated the presence of Ce3+. Notably, among these peaks, v' and u' exhibited the highest intensity in this work. The increase in intensity of u”' was assigned to the increase in CeO2 loadings from 4.50 wt% to 11.40 wt%. Whereas, the presence of v' and u' with strong intensity implies a large amount of Ce3+ in the catalysts. The specific values of the spectral components in Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 (Table S1) suggested that 36 % of the surface Ce ions of Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3 was in Ce3+ state, and Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 had 30 % and 27 % of Ce ions in Ce3+ state, respectively. It was difficult obtained the number of Ce3+ or the concentration of oxygen vacancies by deconvolution of the XPS and Raman spectrum in present work. However, the formation of Ce3+ or oxygen vacancies under reductive atmosphere corresponded to the H2 consumption of H2-TPR peak at <300 °C. And it has been revealed that H2 consumption below 300 °C can be mainly assigned to the reduction of Ce species. Thus, the relative content of Ce3+ or oxygen vacancies in the catalysts was calculated based on the H2 consumption. 3.2 Correlation between catalyst and catalytic performance The catalytic results over Pt-ceria catalysts were displayed in Fig. 8 . The reaction temperature was optimized at 70 °C (Table S2). All the catalysts exhibited a high conversion at similar level. While, the addition of CeO2 in catalysts obviously enhanced the selectivity towards the target product, and the highest selectivity was obtained over Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. The increase in CeO2 loadings (from 4.50 to 11.40 wt%) afforded an increasing selectivity from 75 to 93 %, and a slight lower selectivity was observed over Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 with 16.60 wt% CeO2 loading. Moreover, Pt/Al2O3 with the absence of ceria showed the highest TOF, and TOFs on Pt-Cex/Al2O3 catalysts were close to each other (approx. 0.04 s−1). This may imply Pt species accounted for the hydrogen reaction. Since TOF was calculated based on the platinum concentration determined using ICP, thus, the Pt-ceria catalysts exhibiting a lower TOF compared to Pt/Al2O3 can be assigned to the encapsulation of partial Pt in CeO2 layers. In addition, the effect of H2 pressure on the hydrogen reaction was studied (Fig. S7), a significant decrease in the yield was observed with the decrease in H2 pressure (from 4 to 2PMa). To identity the relationship between catalytic performance and catalyst nature, the selectivity as a function of H2 consumption was plotted in Fig. 9 (a). A higher H2 consumption of the calcinated catalyst gave a higher selectivity towards the target product. And a sharp increase in the selectivity was observed for G1 catalysts which had higher selectivity compared with Pt/Al2O3. Accordingly, this benefited from the presence of CeO2 in the catalysts. To deduce the effect of CeO2 on the reaction, linear fitting of the scatter plot of the selectivity and the H2 consumption was presented in Fig. 9(b), where G2 catalyst was ruled out because of its apparent differences in catalyst structure from G1 catalysts. The results (R2 = 0.997) suggested that the improvement of C5 1,3 diol synthesis was linearly correlated with H2 consumption. It had been suggested the H2 consumption mainly related with CeO2 in the calcinated catalysts, where large amount of the reducible oxygen were involved. Thus, the amount of the reducible oxygen on CeO2 corresponded to the amount of H2 consumption, which indicated that the transformation of the reducible oxygen afforded large amount of the oxygen vacancies. Consequently, this definitively identified the significant importance of oxygen vacancies in this reaction. It has been clarified the Pt dispersion in the catalysts was dependent on the CeO2 dispersion. A uniform distribution of CeO2 provided a good Pt dispersion. This can be assigned to the formation of PtOCe. The reduction of the catalysts gave rise to the appearance of oxygen vacancies which had an ability to trap the metal Pt, resulting in improving the stability of Pt particles. These were supported by reported studies [17,27,33]. Moreover, Zhang et al. clarified that Au atoms were stabilized on the oxygen vacancies of the CeO2 surface based on the density functional theory study [40], and Farmer et al. concluded that Ag particles can be stabilized around the oxygen vacancies on CeO2 (111) by using the calorimetric measurement [41]. In contrast, the agglomeration of CeO2 with non-uniform oxygen vacancies could lead to a poor dispersion of Pt, such as G2 catalyst where partial Pt particles were encapsulated in CeO2 layers, consequently, giving a lower activity. It is widely accepted that the dissociation of H2 provides the hydrogen source for the hydrogenation reactions. And many studies have evidenced the existence of Ce–H hydride species, which clarifies that the H2 dissociation on CeO2 occurs in the presence of oxygen vacancies [42,43]. In addition, Gong et al. suggested that the diffusion of H at the reduced surface can readily occur at a high concentration of the oxygen vacancies, where H also can easily diffuse into the bulk [44]. Pt spilled over H to the neighboring CeO2, where H was trapped by oxygen vacancy giving a large amount of H on CeO2 surface. Moreover, it was suggested that the presence of the oxygen vacancies in supports can facilitate the hydrogen spillover [45,46]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the presence of CeO2 in the catalysts played a key role in catalyst structure (e.g., dispersion, morphology), activating H2 and facilitating the hydrogenation reaction. And all of these benefited from the existence of the oxygen vacancies. 3.3 Influence of Pt on C5 1,3-diol synthesis Fig. 10 illustrates the catalytic results over different catalysts. A 91 % yield at 97 % conversion was obtained over Pt/CeO2, it was slight higher than that over Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 (the optimized catalyst). And the highest yield was obtained over Pt/Ce/Al2O3. The H2 consumption on Pt/Ce/Al2O3 (1.46 wt%, 257 μmol/g) was comparable to Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 (251 μmol/g), which was lower than that on Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 (280 μmol/g). Whereas, Pt/Ce/Al2O3 gave a yield as high as 95 % at 98 % conversion. And the decrease in H2 pressure led to a lower yield, which coincided with the results over Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. Notably, Pt/Ce/Al2O3 was prepared by loading Ce and Pt in sequence, where Ce/Al2O3 (actually, CeO2/Al2O3) can be taken as a support for Pt particles. To understand these, XRD and H2-TPR were performed to clarify the differences in the catalyst properties (Fig. 11 ). XRD patterns illustrated that Pt/Ce/Al2O3 had weakly characteristic peaks of alumina (Fig. 11a). And stronger peaks (at 28.4° and 47.5°) and a weaker peak (at 67.0°) were clearly observed over Pt/Ce/Al2O3 compared with Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. These indicated that the formation of CeO2 as a coat covered the support in Pt/Ce/Al2O3, where Pt mainly dispersed on CeO2 surface. Besides, the increase in the intensity of the peak at 28.4° suggested the appearance of a larger crystallite size of CeO2 in Pt/Ce/Al2O3 compared with Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. H2-TPR curves of the catalysts were displayed in Fig. 11(b), a significant shift of the reduction peak from 230 °C for Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 to 194 °C for Pt/Ce/Al2O3 demonstrated a relatively weak interaction between Pt and Ce/Al2O3. It has been reported that the presence of Pt on CeO2 surface lowers the formation energy of surface oxygen vacancy, whereas, Pt diﬀ ;using into CeO2 leads to the reduction peak shifting to higher temperature [27,47]. In this view, the above mentioned results can be explained by that Pt/Ce/Al2O3 had the Pt on CeO2 surface while Pt was trapped in surface and/or near-surface CeO2 in Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3. Besides, lower reduction temperature inferred the formation of larger Pt particles, which coincided with the XRD results. This was supported by the report from Lee, where it demonstrated that the strong interaction between Pt–O–Ce species and CeO2 can be significantly weakened by the formation of PtO2 species, and the appearance of PtO2 species gave larger Pt particles and lower reduction peaks in H2-TPR curves, consequently, affording an enhanced activity for the reaction. On the other hand, Ce/Pt/Al2O3 exhibited a much lower activity with a 77 % yield (Table S3). Ce/Pt/Al2O3 was prepared by impregnating Pt and Ce in sequence, consequently, encapsulating Pt in CeO2 layer. Therefore, higher activity over Pt/Ce/Al2O3 compared with Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 can be owed to the Pt particles dispersing on CeO2 surface with relatively larger size, which benefited from Pt weakly interacting with Ce/Al2O3. In summary, for the synthesis of C5 1,3-diol from MEK-formaldehyde adduct over Pt-ceria catalyst, it can be concluded that the presence of CeO2 appeared to be essential for the catalyst structure (e.g., dispersion, morphology) and enhanced catalytic performance (e.g., activating H2, facilitating the reaction) due to the presence of the oxygen vacancies, and the significant importance of Pt itself (e.g., particle size, location) for this reaction was also deduced. 3.4 Application of C5 1,3-diol in isoprene production Isoprene is among the most important building blocks for synthesizing rubber. The efficient transformation of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol to isoprene shed light on the probability of a application of non-linear C5 1,3-diols in isoprene production. The as synthesized 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol was transformed to isoprene in the presence of heteropolyacid catalysts. The results were presented in Fig. 12 . These catalyst gave a good yield of isoprene (about 80 %), without the formation of cyclic ethers. These may benefit from the readily and efficiently transform of the non-linear 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol because of its two hydroxyl groups at the meta-position. These results verified that nonlinear C5 1,3-diols were desirable candidates for isoprene production. 4 Conclusions A C5 1,3-diol (2-methyl-1,3-butanediol) was synthesized from MEK and formaldehyde. Ceria was used to modify the Pt-based catalysts with different methods and employed for the hydrogen reaction. Pt-Cex/Al2O3 catalysts, prepared by impregnating Al2O3 with a solution containing Pt and Ce, gave the yields as an order: Pt-Ce4.50/Al2O3 < Pt-Ce9.18/Al2O3 < Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 > Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 with the increasing of the CeO2 content (4.50, 9.18, 11.40, 16.60 wt%). This was due to the significant differences in catalyst structure between Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3 having a high CeO2 content and the catalysts having a relative low CeO2 content. A high CeO2 content led to the agglomeration of CeO2, which afforded a poor Pt dispersion because of the dependence of Pt dispersion on CeO2 dispersion. In addition, it deduced that the Pt particles were encapsulated in CeO2 atom layers for Pt-Ce16.60/Al2O3, while they were trapped in surface and/or near-surface CeO2 layers for these catalysts with low CeO2 content. Consequently, the presence of CeO2 appeared to be essential for the catalyst structure (e.g., dispersion, morphology) and enhanced catalytic performance (e.g., activating H2, facilitating the reaction) due to the presence of the oxygen vacancies. The highest yield (95 %) was obtained over Pt/Ce/Al2O3 which was prepared by loading Ce and Pt on Al2O3 in sequence. XRD identified a larger crystallite size of CeO2 in Pt/Ce/Al2O3 compared with Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3, and the shift of H2-TPR peak to lower temperature implied the relatively weak interaction between Pt and Ce/Al2O3 in Pt/Ce/Al2O3. These demonstrated a larger Pt particles dispersed on Ce/Al2O3 surface. And the comparison between Pt/Ce/Al2O3 and Pt-Ce11.40/Al2O3 clarified the significant importance of Pt itself (e.g., particle size, location) for this reaction. Finally, the application of the as-synthesized 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol was explored in isoprene production in the presence of common heteropolyacid catalysts, affording isoprene in ∼80 % yield. coredata.dc:description: Isoprene has outmost importance in the manufacture of elastomer. Herein, an alternative approach for isoprene production from readily available chemicals is reported: condensation of methyl ethyl ketone and formaldehyde, followed by the hydrogenation and dehydration reaction. The focus was paid on the hydrogenation reaction over Pt-ceria catalysts giving 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol, where the influence of Ce species on the catalyst structure was studied, and the structure-activity relationship was established. It deduced that the presence of CeO2 appeared to be essential for the catalyst structure (e.g., dispersion, morphology) and the enhanced catalytic performance (e.g., activating H2, facilitating the reaction), these benefited from the presence of the oxygen vacancies on CeO2 surface. In addition, a relatively weak Pt-support interaction gave larger Pt particles which resulted in a higher yield. Finally, the application of the as-synthesized 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol in isoprene production was performed in the presence of the heteropolyacid catalysts, affording isoprene in ∼80 % yield.
coredata.dc:title: Converting formaldehyde-methylethylketone adduct to a nonlinear C5 1,3-diol over Pt-ceria catalysts for isoprene production
